awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Selection Methods for Algebraic Design of Experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
Data science has emerged as an important field for making decisions based on data collected from sectors as varied as healthcare and housing.  Though data are plentiful, thanks to phone apps, merchant loyalty cards, and social media accounts, there is still a question of whether more data translates to more knowledge. Furthermore collection and storage can be problematic especially when data are sensitive, as it is often the case with clinical trials and genetic experiments.  The problem of selecting information-rich data becomes crucial for creating models that can reliably predict the outcome of future experiments. Few results have been published on the amount of necessary data, and currently there are no guidelines for generating specific data sets which would unambiguously identify a predictive model. As a first step towards developing a complete theory, the PIs will focus on models described by finite-valued nonlinear polynomial functions. (For example, the internal 'function' in WedMD's Symptom Checker returns medical conditions according to symptoms input by the user.)  They will construct the smallest data sets that have a single associated polynomial model and study properties of such data sets.  From these computational experiments, they will build the appropriate theory, design algorithms, and generate code that can be later developed into software complete with a graphical user interface. Graduate students will participate at the appropriate level of each component of the project. Such an experience will provide them possible topics for an MS or PhD dissertation and will very likely inspire a career-long involvement in the STEM disciplines. The theoretical results will advance the fields of design of experiments, network inference, and finite dynamical systems through the determination of criteria for selecting data sets to uniquely identify models. The algorithms will serve as a guide for experimentalists in determining the data that are needed to identify the structure of a network of interest. Such knowledge has the potential to drastically reduce wasted resources that arise from too much data with too little information.

While this is the age of big data, there is still a question of whether more data translates to more knowledge. Particularly when collecting data is expensive or time consuming, as it is often the case with clinical trials and biomolecular experiments, the problem of selecting information-rich data becomes crucial for creating relevant models. Finite-state multivariate polynomial functions have successfully been used to model complex networks from discretized data; however, few results have been published on the amount of data necessary for such models, with the majority applying to Boolean models only. It is still unknown which data points explicitly identify such discrete models, and as a consequence, there are no methods for generating the specific data sets which would unambiguously identify the model.  The PIs will address the issue of the minimality and specificity of data to uniquely identify discrete polynomial models by developing the appropriate theory, designing algorithms, and generating code that can be later built into software. Graduate students will participate at the appropriate level of each component of the project. This project will resolve some important computational issues in network inference and will improve experimental design and model selection by eliminating the effect of computational artifacts that arise when working with nonlinear multivariate polynomials. The theoretical results will advance the fields of design of experiments and network inference through the establishment of criteria to select data sets to uniquely identify models. The proposed work will also increase the utility of polynomial dynamical systems as models of complex networks by establishing the minimal amount of the data for unique model identification. The algorithms will serve as a guide for experimentalists in determining the data that are needed to identify the structure of a network of interest. Such knowledge has the potential to drastically reduce the number of experiments performed and to eliminate the generation of data with little intrinsic value.

por.por_cntn:
Biological data science is a field replete with many substantial data sets from laboratory experiments and myriad diverse methods for analysis and modeling.  Given the abundance of both data and models, there is a growing need to group data sets to reveal salient features of the data and untimely of the underlying network.   For discrete data, a special class of discrete models called polynomial dynamical systems can be used to capture all models which fit the given data.  Typically a data set can have a large number of associated models, requiring model selection.  In the face of limited understanding of the underlying network, selecting models which accurate reflect the network can be challenging.

The primary focus of this project is to identify discrete data sets which guarantee a unique polynomial dynamical system and to develop relevant algorithms, involving undergraduate and graduate students in all aspects of the theoretical and computational work.

The problem translates mathematically to identifying data sets V with an ideal of points I(V) having a unique reduced Groebner basis (URGB) for any monomial ordering. PI Brandilyn Stigler and collaborators discovered a necessary and sufficient condition on I(V) that guarantees that it has a URGB.  In fact it is an algebraic property on the generators of I(V) that can be easily checked.  They also discovered two separate sufficient conditions on the data for I(V) to have a URGB:  if V is the linear shift of a staircase (a geometric property) and if V is the variety of the distraction of some monomial ideal (an algebraic property). 

Since they were interested in grouping data, they used linear shifts to partition data into equivalence classes and showed that each equivalence class has an associated collection of monomial bases, that is monomials which make up the polynomial dynamical system. In addition, they defined a type of "standard position" for data: data points that are configured as staircases, that is contiguous and condensed, are in standard position.  Such data sets minimize the number of nodes that are active, thereby potentially improving model predictability.

They improved an existing upper bound on the number of reduced Groebner bases associated with small data sets.  They also found an interesting divisibility property of the sizes of the equivalence classes, which may be a stepping stone for finding a formula for the number of reduced Groebner bases for an ideal of points.

The results of this project were disseminated in 4 articles published in peer-reviewed internationally recognized journals. Additionally Stigler presented at 12 venues, including 3 national/international conferences, 4 regional meetings, and 5 external departmental colloquia.  She also gave a keynote address discussing results from this project at a regional conference.  The supported PhD student Anyu Zhang gave oral and poster presentations at 6 venues, including 4 national/international conferences, 1 regional meeting, and 1 local symposium.

Another key outcome of this project is a publicly available website, developed by Zhang, providing researchers access to a database of precomputed datasets and associated sets of monomial bases which can be queried.  The website DoEMS (pronounced "domes") is an algebraic-geometric platform for combining design of experiments and model selection. Details are in the 2022 paper “Algebraic model selection and experimental design in biological data science” published in Advances in Applied Mathematics.  The website is available at https://s2.smu.edu/doems/.

These results increase the utility of polynomial dynamical systems as models of complex networks by establishing the minimal amount of the data for unique model identification, thus contributing to the areas of mathematical biology, systems biology, and bioinformatics. Specifically, the database accessible via the website confers the following advantage for researchers: without having to perform computations, a modeler can quickly identify which model bases correspond to which data sets, thereby performing experimental design and model selection simultaneously.

This project provided multiple opportunities for training, development, and support of young researchers.  Primarily it provided a research assistantship for a female mathematics PhD student (Zhang) who successfully completed her degree with a dissertation entitled “Model Selection and Experimental Design of Biological Networks with Algebraic Geometry”.  She is now employed as a data scientist at a Big Tech company.  Secondarily it provided financial support for both Stigler and Zhang to perform and present the results of this project.  Furthermore they also co-organized a session with entitled "Data-Driven Approaches in the Life Sciences" at the SIAM Conference on Applications of Dynamical Systems in Year 2 of the project.  Stigler also co-organized with a pre-tenure professor a session entitled "New Developments in Algebraic Biology" at the AWM Research Symposium at Rice University in the same year.  Finally coauthors of the published works include one female undergraduate student, two graduate students (one of which is female), one postdoctoral researcher, one associate professor (female), and one full professor.  The supported PhD student contributed to three of the manuscripts.
